Problem:
Consider a complex function defined by \\( z(t) = e^{i\omega t} \\), where \\( \omega \\) is a real constant and \\( i \\) is the imaginary unit. We examine the effect of a linear transformation defined by the matrix \\( A \\), where \\( A = \\begin{pmatrix} \cos \phi & -\sin \phi \\ \sin \phi & \cos \phi \\end{pmatrix} \\) representing a rotation by an angle \\( \phi \\) on the complex plane.

If \\( A \\) is applied to \\( z(t) \\) at t = 0, and then allowed to evolve naturally under \\( z(t) = e^{i\omega t} \\) without further intervention, will the trajectory of \\( z(t) \\) at later times t > 0 remain a circle centered at the origin on the complex plane?
Explanation: The application of matrix \\( A \\) at the initial stage is a rotation, which preserves the magnitude of \\( z(t) = e^{i\omega t} \\). Since \\( e^{i\omega t} \\) describes a circle on the complex plane, rotating this circle by any angle \\( \phi \\) still results in a circle centered at the origin.
